we have discovered that it quite
important to keep up the morale of the

Are War Stamps and Bonds Suitable as Trophies?
question of the advisability of giving thrift stamps and Liberty
Bonds as athletic trophies is puzzling the authorities this season. The
& of course, is excellent, the intent being to stimulate the sale and
mulation of Uncle Sam's war securities and the advertising of the

Philadelphia golfers will remember the
old fourth as the first short hole played
after the meadow holes. The new hole |
will be a full wooden shot with a yard-
age of 180, beautifully trapped and with |
the green elevated and undulated as is
the present’,third, The green itself is
in fine but the condition of the
ground immediately in front of the green
is the bothersome part of the hole, and
unless this can be gotten into playing
condition the club will not use it, and
the golfers, after playing the third, will
walk over to the fifth tee.

100-Game Catcher Worth Big Salary
TCHER who works in at least 100 games each season is worth a
e salary. Last year’s major league records show that these men
century mark behind the bat: National League, Killefer and
ei h 120 games, and Rariden, 100. American League, Schalk and
_@ach 139 games; O'Neill, 1 and Ainsmith, 119. Those who
ttween 90 and 100 games were Stanage, of Detroit; Nunamaker,
fan ; Miller, of Brooklyn; Snyder, of the Cardinals, and Tra-
of the Braves. Hannah, the Yankee’s new receiver, led the coun-
#5 games, of which 100 were caughf by him without a layoff

clinches in tossing away the hard-press-

For the first five rounds the fight was
close, with Tendler having a shade in
the first, second and fifth. In the sixth,
Tendler opened up his attack and de-
livered many slashing rights to
head and lefts to the body that Jackson
was forced to hold. Just before the end
of the round Tendler halted his attack
and wrestied for the remaining thirty
seconds This was not explained until
Lew was seen in his dressing room, when
it was only too apparent that his left
thumb was swollen almost twice its
normal size He injured his left when
he directed one for the jaw, which
missed fire and nailed Jackson on the
shoulder.

Jackson made his best syewing in the
seventh round when he set a wicked
for half the session, but his rally
died out‘and Tendler showed enough aft
the finish to earn an even break, From
the eighth to the end there never was
any doubt and the 2500 fans
the right of rooting clapped continuously,

In the ninth Tendler switched his at-
tack from the head and concentrated
upon the body and gained results. He
the
stomach, any one of which seemed capa-
ble of forcing Jackson to clinch, but the
more they landed the more speed Jack-
son generated, The tenth found Lew

left thumb. Lew also was hit
low, for his cup was badly dented, Jack-

170 yards, and is a
big improvement over the old and
shorter hole This hole was changed
last fall, and the members are delighted
with the change. There is a néw trap
on the first fairway to catch a topped
ball, and there are minor changes on
several cther holes, The traps, bunkers
and pits have been raked and are ready
for niblic play. -

ber of Metropolitan golfers will also
play in the tournament, and at least
four score of Philadelphians will be
among the entrants. Maurice Risley

ment, will be playing in those famous
